verdict.summary: Build tools (webpack, TypeScript, Jest) cannot locate the react/jsx-runtime module introduced in React 17's new JSX transform. Happens when React version is too old, tsconfig uses the wrong jsx option, or the module resolution can't find the package.

dead_ends.action: Adding /** @jsxRuntime classic */ pragma to every file
dead_ends.why_fails: This falls back to the old React.createElement transform per-file, which defeats the purpose of the new JSX transform (smaller bundles, no React import needed). It doesn't fix the underlying configuration issue and creates tech debt.

dead_ends.action: Downgrading to React 16 to avoid the new JSX transform
dead_ends.why_fails: React 16 lacks key features (concurrent rendering, automatic batching, useId). The jsx-runtime issue is a configuration problem, not a React version problem. React 17+ is needed for the new transform.

workarounds.action: Ensure React version is 17+ and properly installed in node_modules
workarounds.how:
npm ls react
# If version < 17, upgrade:
npm install react@latest react-dom@latest
# Verify the file exists:
ls node_modules/react/jsx-runtime.js

workarounds.action: For Jest, configure the test environment to use the new JSX transform
workarounds.condition: Error occurs only in Jest tests

frequently_confused_with.distinction: 'react/jsx-runtime' not found is a build configuration issue with the JSX transform mode. 'react-dom/client' not found means React 18's createRoot API is being used with React 17 or older react-dom installed.
